sentence.text: ﻿Case 3 is a male in his 20s born to Swiss unrelated parents.
He was born by caesarean section at term with a weight of 2570 g and a length of 45 cm.

Postaxial polydactyly of the hands, preaxial polydactyly of the feet, and facial dysmorphism such as a bulging forehead with receding hair line, bilateral epicanthus, mild down-slant of narrow palpebral fissures, hypertelorism, scarce upper eyelashes and absent lower eyelashes, convergent strabismus and bilateral pits of the ear lobes were noted.

Moreover, he had pseudarthrosis of the right clavicle, hypospadias, bilateral inguinal hernias, right-sided cryptorchidism, widely spaced nipples, a large fontanel (6×6 cm), bifid uvula, and a short neck.
The diagnosis of ACLS was proposed.

Cerebral ultrasound investigations revealed enlarged lateral ventricles and a suspicion of corpus callosum hypoplasia, which was said to have been confirmed by Computed Tomography (CT) imaging during childhood.
At the age of 4 months, measurements were 61 cm length (3rd centile), 6020 g weight (10th centile), 42.5 cm HC (25th centile), and a 7×8 cm open fontanel.
Already at this time, a developmental delay of 2 months was noted and a hypoplastic optic nerve disc was mentioned.
At the age of 7 years, when the boy was given to foster parents, he could hardly walk, had hardly any speech, and very low vision.
At the age of 14 years, he underwent normal puberty.
Since the age of 15 years he had bladder control both day and night and no longer needed diapers (nappies).
At the age of 18 years he still had limited beard growth and scarce axillary hair.
It was said that he had tunnel vision and that an electroretinogram at the age of 5.75 years had shown abnormal results, arguing for a retinopathy.
His height was reported to be 185 cm (90th centile), weight 7.2 kg (75–90th centile), and HC 58 cm (75–90th centile).
Ear length was asymmetric with 7 cm on the left side and 6.3 cm on the right side.
Ears were low set and posteriorly rotated, with an underfolded apical helix and hypoplastic lobes.
The forehead was high and broad, palpebral fissures were narrow with mild epicanthal folds and mild down-slant.
The nasal bridge was broad, and the philtrum short and prominent.
Lips were full and everted with a median groove in the upper lip, and the tongue was large.
The neck was short with a low hair line and a flat occiput.
Fingers were tapering with limited distal interphalangeal joint mobility of the fifth fingers.
He was said to occasionally have temper tantrums with destructiveness.

At the age of 21 years he was able to walk freely, but in small steps with flexion contracture of knees up to 1 km, to ride a tandem bike, to swim, to get himself dressed apart from closing zippers and putting on socks, and to cut food.
Due to calcaneous-valgus deformity, he needed ortheses.
He had a limited vision with very high myopia, nystagmus, and nasal, inarticulate speech.
He had a good memory, was able to count to 30 and to communicate well, but was unable to read or write.
He had become obese with a height of 183 cm (>75th centile) and weight of 94.5 kg (>97th centile).

We identified two KIF7 heterozygous mutations: a substitution at the acceptor splice site of intron 12 c.2593-3C>G inherited from the father, and a nonsense mutation in exon 15 (c.3001C>T, p.Gln1001X) inherited from his mother.

The c.2593-3C>G variation is absent from SNP databases and 1000 genomes, and its in silico analysis by Human Splicing Finder (see URLs) shows a reduced score of intron 12 acceptor splice site from 86 to 74, while it is abolished with NNSPLICE 0.9 (see URLs).
The sister of the mother also had a daughter with polydactyly and a clinical diagnosis of acrocallosal or Mohr syndrome, but was not interested in further investigations.
